thread.title: Irish border backstop deal needed by June - Irish Deputy PM

title: Irish border backstop deal needed by June - Irish Deputy PM
text: March 26, 2018 / 10:25 AM / Updated 27 minutes ago Irish border backstop deal needed by June - Irish Deputy PM Reuters Staff 1 Min Read STOCKHOLM (Reuters) - Failure to reach a backstop deal for the border between the Irish Republic and British-ruled Northern Ireland by June could put the UK’s final withdrawal agreement from the European Union at risk, Ireland’s deputy prime minister said on Monday. A road which crosses the border from County Donegal in Ireland to County Londonderry in Northern Ireland, is seen from near the border village of Lenamore, Ireland. There are no markings apart from the change in roadsigns. REUTERS/Clodagh Kilcoyne “We have to try to get a withdrawal agreement and a withdrawal treaty signed off on before October, and I think on that particular issue Ireland has a very specific issue ... and that’s the Irish border issue,” Deputy Prime Minister Simon Coveney said during a visit to Sweden. “Hopefully we can have that done by June, but if we don’t have it done by June, then I think obviously, we have to raise some serious questions as to whether it is possible to finalise a withdrawal treaty at all.” Reporting by Simon Johnson; Editing by Gareth Jones
